a0oa6y.desc:
[MA] To start, I’m epileptic, have been taking medicine since I was 10, but grand mals are very rare for me. 

I’ve been taking the generic brand for awhile now, supposed to be the same thing.

I called my neurologist to get a refill, and asked it to be sent to my normal pharmacy. The woman on the phone confirmed the pharmacy with me twice, including repeating the address.

She sends it to the wrong one, one I used several years ago somehow. 

I take my medicine, something doesn’t feel quite right, I don’t feel as stable. I keep taking it.

I then have TWO grand mal seizures, I had to be hospitalized overnight, missed a week of work, including important calls/demos with Halliburton, OshKosh Trucks, Dell, and John Deere the day it happened. I’ve  never had aftermath like this before, it was bad. Happened a full month ago and I still feel some residual effects in my shoulders (dislocated) and nose (hit my face on bathroom tile). In the past I’ve gone to work the next day. 

I look at my bottle and I see it’s from a different manufacturer.

I read up, and formulas can vary by 30%, and the one I had been taking for years was closest to name brand. Others had similar experiences feeling that a diff manufacturer was like not taking meds at all. 

I managed to find name brand, and I started getting double vision for a couple days (a normal side effect with a too-high dose) because of the difference in strength from what I was dispensed and the normal medication.

I luckily have phenomenal health insurance through my work so I don’t believe I’ll end up having to pay a dime even with the hospital ride (first one happened at my house, I went to the community health center near my house, they sent me to the hospital in an ambulance. Had the second at the hospital) 

Is there something I should do about this? Is it my fault for not noticing it was a different manufacturer? I feel like it’s not ok to send to the wrong pharmacy then receive a diff version without being told. Even when I used to pick up there, it was my correct version. When the tablet changed shape there was even a notification on my bottle.

Tldr: nurse sent script to wrong pharmacy, diff manufacturer on meds without being told, had two grand mal seizures
a0oa6y.topComment:

a0ofld.desc:
I (21, F) have a credit score of 781, but only one credit card to my name, no other major loans, (student, auto, etc. I paid cash for my car and sold it for the same when I was done with it.) I applied for another card a while back that doesn’t charge international fees (because I’m blessed with the ability to travel somewhat frequently) but got turned down for lack of credit. 

I was thinking about getting a Target red card just for the sake of opening another low-maintenance card.  Where I am in the city is sort of food-locked, so I end up buying most of my groceries, pharmaceutical needs and household supplies at Target. Again, I don’t ever anticipate a purchase there that would put me in even remote danger of needing to only pay the minimal payment and getting hit with their 24.65% Variable APR, because I make all these purchases off of my debit card already. Is the 5% off purchase worth it? Should I get a RED debit card and look into some other credit building opportunities?

Any advice is appreciated!
a0ofld.topComment:
Target CC has a setting on it to autopay every month. I use it whenever I’m at target and get the 5% and it never has a balance so I never pay them any interest. Be sure when you buy you can pay when they autopay. I also do this on my Amazon/Chase card. Like any CC you have to have discipline to not pay the rich corporate fat guy interest  

Note that Target also has a debit card that takes money out of your debit card at the time of transaction and you still get 5% but it’s not a CC and won’t do anything for credit
a0ofld.title: are store cards a decent way to build credit?

a0psmf.desc: My husband is the executor of his uncle’s estate, as my husband is the next and last of kin. As we were going over uncle’s accounts once uncle passed away, we were surprised to discover over $17k worth of charges spread over his checking and a few credit cards. I called around and quickly found out that a cousin had used those cards while he was dying in a nursing home and she continued briefly after he died, until we closed everything. She took a road trip across the country and placed charges in dozens of cities and several states. We have pressed charges in one city in which she made a big chunk of charges, but what else can we do? One credit card company will not refund the charges ($4k air bnb) because the account was closed upon uncle’s death and they can’t retroacfively open a fraud claim. We’ve been told that we could contact each individual city in which she used the cards to press charges but it was hard enough just to file in one city. Is there anything else we can do? We have an estate lawyer but he was pretty clueless about this other than suggesting we let the credit card company open a claim for the unpaid balance and we can counter as fraud. Tldr; My husband’s cousin is a terrible person who stole her dying great uncle’s wallet and now we’re paying for her crime. (FL)
